Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Dispersion and Selective Positioning of Reinforcement in Polymer Matrix Composites

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Composite materials made with ceramic reinforcements in a polymer matrix offer features of high strength-to-weight ratio, flexibility, and flaw tolerance. One advantage for discontinuous (short) fiber-reinforced composites is the ease of manufacturing complex shaped parts. One disadvantage, however, is reduced strength as compared to continuous (long) fiber-reinforced composites, due to stress concentrations at the fiber ends in the composite during use. This stress localization at the ends of fibers can lead to bond failure between the matrix and fiber reinforcement causing cracks that lead to material failure. The novelty of this project's process is the ability to selectively position a range of particle sizes near the fiber ends to help reinforce and distribute the stress in that zone. This will result in higher strength for composite parts made with discontinuous fiber reinforcement, helping to enable low cost manufacturing of parts with intricate geometries.

This EArly-Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project will investigate the homogeneity, stability and reproducibility for fabricating and dispersing suspensions of colloidally-assembled hierarchical ceramic fillers for discontinuous fiber composites. These new materials are predicted to push discontinuous fiber composites toward the holy grail of increased strength and ductility, a combination that is not attainable in most material systems. When these hierarchical assemblies are incorporated into a polymer matrix, the polymer will infiltrate the near-interface of the assemblies to form an interphase region of enhanced mechanical stiffness that encompasses the even stiffer ceramic particles. This new perspective offers a material independent methodology for increasing the properties and performance of discontinuous fiber composites, while maintaining compatibility with bulk, economic, and facile manufacturing techniques such as injection molding, tape-casting or hot-pressing. This research project will answer several fundamental questions associated with stress transfer and failure mechanisms for materials consisting of dissimilar components, and also take advantage of emerging technologies that enable processing of composites with hierarchical morphology (i.e., stepping between macro- micro- and nano- regimes). The work will also provide insight toward the challenges associated with fabrication (i.e., dispersion and preparation) as well as reproducibility and reliability of the composite manufacturing process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major research goal of this one-year EAGER proposal was to study and characterize the homogeneity, stability and reproducibility of the colloidal suspensions that are precursors to graded discontinuous fiber composites (DFCs). This new class of composites is predicted to increase both the strength and the strain at rupture of these materials making DFC performance comparable to continuous fiber composites that currently dominate high-load composite material markets. Instead, DFCs would offer significant advantages including lower costs, easier processing, and access to intricate geometries. Also, graded discontinuous reinforcement architectures are also intellectually fascinating. The predicted increase of both strength and ductility is a desirable rarity. This project enables us to investigate and understand aspects of these graded architectures, both experimentally and theoretically, that will contribute to the understanding of material structure/performance relationships that are both multi-scale and interfacially derived.

In addition to reducing stress and strain around the fibers, a graded architecture may also inherently help strengthen fiber-matrix interfaces by reducing the mechanical and thermal mismatches between adjacent materials. Such mismatches lead to premature interfacial failure in a large variety of fields from biomedical implants in orthopedics to metal-composite joints in automotive and aerospace applications to inorganic functional devices in high-performance flexible electronics. Increasing interfacial performance using graded architectures is a material non-specific methodology that has the potential to shift the paradigm in many diverse fields.

In this one year project, we established protocols for making homogenous dispersions of hierarchical particle assemblies and casting these dispersions into homogeneous films. We conducted significant mechanical tests across the design space and found that graded reinforcement architectures do indeed provide superior mechanical properties including the combination of high stiffness and high strain at rupture (as was predicted in our proposal). Overall, we have successfully demonstrated that we can make homogenous dispersion of hierarchical particle assemblies that can be effectively incorporated into homogenous polymer composites. The resulting mechanical properties are outstanding, showing a combination of high stiffness and high strain at rupture.

In addition, the major educational and outreach goals of this EAGER proposal were to build new forums that link graduate, undergraduate, young scholar, and the general public audiences with effective research dissemination. We have conducted several educational and outreach activities to meet these goals. This one-year project allowed us to recruit and train two (2) graduate students. These graduate students (one full time and one part time) learned colloidal processing techniques (e.g. van der Waals interactions, electrostatic assembly processes), composite process techniques (e.g. tape-casting, screen-printing, mold casting), polymer characterization techniques (e.g., DSC, XRD, TGA, and DMA), and material analysis (e.g., tensile testing, freeze-fracturing, SEM). We have hosted two undergraduate students per semester to work with our graduate students on this project. This project also allowed us to host two high school student participants from the Summer 2015 Young Scholar Program (YSP) hosted by the Northeastern University Center for STEM to perform research on the crystallization kinetics of our polymer suspensions with our hybrid particles.

To share this work, we have given presentations at national conferences, campus visits, and to local industries. The results of this project have been disseminated to communities of interest in a variety of formats including in the preparation of a journal manuscript, being presented...
